# 2026 Compensation Table

For accidents occurring or expenses incurred between January 1, 2026 and December 31, 2026

| | |
| --- | --- |
| Indemnity | Amount90% of net income calculated on the basisof a gross annual income of up to $102,500For examples of the calculation, refer to thenext page. |
| Income replacementindemnity1,2 |
| Indemnity forcare expenses | Weekly amount:$552 for one person$619 for two people$683 for three people$753 for four or more people |
| Lump-sum indemnityfor students | $6,612 per school year lost at theelementary level$12,135 per school year lost at thesecondary level$12,135 per term lost at the post-secondarylevel, up to $24,268 per year |
| Income replacementindemnity (after thescheduled date ofcompletion of studies) | Students may be entitled to receive anindemnity based on the average earningsof Québec workers, which correspondsto $62,281 |
| Lump-sum indemnity forpermanent impairment | Up to $309,443 |
| Indemnity for injury | -Up to $1,769 |

1. When an accident victim who has been receiving an income replacement indemnity turns 65, the amount of their indemnity is reduced by $2 5 %$ . When they turn 66, it is reduced by $5 0 % ,$ and when they turn 67, it is reduced by $7 5 %$ . Once the beneficiary turns 68, the income replacement indemnity is based on a new calculation and is payable up until death.

2. In the case of an accident victim who has sustained injury or impairment granting entitlement to an income replacement indemnity based at a minimum on the average annual earnings of Québec workers, as of the first-year anniversary of the accident, that person's income replacement indemnity is calculated on the basis of a gross annual income that is not lower than $62,281.

The income replacement indemnity is calculated based on the accident victim's net annual income. This income corresponds to the gross annual income from which deductions equivalent to the following have been made:

- Québec Pension Plan (QPP) contributions;

- Employment Insurance (EI) premiums;

- Québec Parental Insurance Plan (QPIP) premiums;

- income tax.

| | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Gross annual income | $33,580(minimumincome) | $70,000 | $102,500(maximumincome) |
| Minus theamountsequivalentto: | QPP contributions | $1,895 | $4,190 | $4,895 |
| El premiums | $437 | $896 | $896 |
| QPIP premiums | $144 | $301 | $441 |
| Provincialincome tax | $2,048 | $7,929 | $14,104 |
| Federalincome tax | $1,713 | $5,961 | $11,379 |
| Net annual income | $27,343 | $50,723 | $70,785 |
| Annual income replacementindemnity(annual net income x 90%) | $24,609 | $45,651 | $63,707 |
| Payment every two weeks(amount of the annual indemnity÷ 365 days x 14 days) | $944 | $1,751 | $2,444 |

- These examples show the calculations for a person who does not have a spouse or dependants. The actual amounts can vary depending on each accident victim's family situation.

- Amounts have been rounded off to the nearest dollar.

The SAAQ indexes the amount of most indemnities on a yearly basis. To receive your copy of the updated compensation table, available at the beginning of each year, please write to:

Direction générale des communications

Société de l'assurance automobile du Québec

Case postale 19600, succursale Terminus

333, boulevard Jean-Lesage

Québec (Québec) G1K 8J6

# 2026 Death Benefits Table

# Please note:

Though "estate" is the more common term, "succession" is used in this table, as it is the term used in Québec legislation.

For accidents and deaths occurring between January 1, 2026 and December 31, 2026

Lump-Sum Death Benefit

# Accident victim without a spouse or dependants

In the case of an accident victim who leaves behind no spouse or dependants, a lump-sum death benefit in the amount of $$ 70,730$ is divided equally between the victim's mother and father (if the victim was a minor at the time of death) or paid to the succession (if the victim had reached the age of majority).

# Surviving spouse

The lump-sum death benefit paid to the accident victim's surviving spouse is established on the basis of the victim's gross income multiplied by a factor of 5. The maximum gross income for the purposes of calculating the benefit is $$ 102,500$ . The benefit will never be less than $172,914 nor higher than $512,500.

# For example:

# For example:

The surviving spouse of an accident victim whose gross annual income was $$ 40,000$ will be paid a lump-sum death benefit of $$ 200,000$ $( 5 4 0 , 0 0 0 \\times 5 = 5 2 0 0 , 0 0 0 )$ ).

The surviving spouse of an accident victim whose gross annual income was $$ 20,000$ will be paid a lump-sum death benefit of $172,914 $( 5 2 0 , 0 0 0 \\times 5 = 5 1 0 0 , 0 0 0 )$ .

The surviving spouse of an accident victim whose gross annual income was $110,000 will be paid a lump-sum death benefit of $512,500 $( 5 1 1 0 , 0 0 0 \\times 5 = 5 5 0 , 0 0 0 )$ .

# Dependants

Each of an accident victim's dependants, other than their spouse, is paid a lump-sum death benefit, the amount of which is established according to the dependant's age at the time of the victim's death, as follows:

| | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Dependant's age (years) | Amount | Dependant's age (years) | Amount |
| Younger than one year | $77,219 | 9 | $57,367 |
| 1 | $75,013 | 10 | $55,154 |
| 2 | $72,806 | 1 1 | $52,951 |
| 3 | $70,598 | 12 | $50,745 |
| 4 | $68,389 | 13 | $48,539 |
| 5 | $66,184 | 14 | $46,332 |
| 6 | $63,984 | 15 | $44,127 |
| 7 | $61,774 | 16 or older | $41,914 |
| 8 | $59,569 | | |

- If a dependant other than the spouse is disabled at the time of the accident victim's death, they are entitled to an additional lump-sum benefit of $36,400.

- If a dependant other than the spouse is disabled at the time of the accident victim's death, they are entitled to an additional lump-sum benefit of $36,400.

- Children of an accident victim who had no spouse will also receive, in addition to their own indemnity, the lump-sum benefit that would have been paid to the spouse, divided equally among them.

# Indemnity To Cover Funeral Expenses

An amount of $8,727 is paid to the accident victim's succession.

# Availability Allowance

If the accident victim was hospitalized and survived the accident for some time before their death, members of the immediate family are entitled to an availability allowance if the presence of a relative was required for medical reasons:

- up to $$ 41$ for availability of four hours or less;

- up to $$ 82$ for availability of more than four hours.

The SAAQ indexes the amount of most benefits on a yearly basis. To receive your copy of the updated compensation table, available at the beginning of each year, please write to:

Direction générale des communications

Société de l'assurance automobile du Québec

Case postale 19600, succursale Terminus

333, boulevard Jean-Lesage

Québec (Québec) G1K 8J6

Original text in French

Note: This folder is not a text of law. For questions of a legal nature, please refer to the Automobile Insurance Act and attendant regulations.

Avec vous, au coeur de votre sécurite
